title: About
text:
Interdisciplinary researcher, collaborator, and information technology professional with over ten years of experience in scientific computing and computational research applications across STEM and non-STEM areas.
My focus is in applying advanced High-Performance Computing (HPC) capabilities to enhance research throughput that involves closely collaborating with a diverse research community.
Using HPC and other advanced scientific computing techniques is essential to expand research by developing computational protocols to study heavy element chemistry with national security and other applications.

title: Hoffman2 Happy Hour - Rstudio
text:
This Workshop took place via Zoom on March 30, 2022.
The repo containing the pdf and zoom recording is located on UCLA’s IDRE github site
https://github.com/ucla-oarc-hpc/hpc_workshops
This was based on using Rstudio on UCLA’s Hoffman2 resource. I had setup a Container with Rstudio Server that can be used on Hoffman2.
Stay tuned for more workshops from the Hoffman2 Team!

title: UCLA Singularity Workshop
text:
This Workshop took place via Zoom on April 29, 2021.
The repo containing the pdf and zoom recording is located on UCLA’s IDRE gitlab site
https://github.com/ucla-oarc-hpc/hpc_workshops
The is workshop is a basic lecture on using singularity to using containers on Hoffman2.
There are example containers in the gitlab repo, showing sample containers of with python and packages like TensorFlow and PySCF. Also a example using GPU containers.
Stay tuned for more updates on Singularity on Hoffman2!

title: Quill Program for SCF calucations
text:
I have updated on GitHub a small, very simple Hartree Fock program, mostly written in C. I mostly wrote this code as a test to program Hartree Fock. I am thinking of adding more functions.
The code is located on my GitHub page https://github.com/charliecpeterson/QUILL
This program uses PySCF and libcint to generate the 1e/2e integrals. It also uses the Eigen3 API for all Matrix/linear algbra routines.
The input is very similar to NWChem. In the GitHub repo, there is a sample input input.inp

As of now, there are only three input blocks that is code accepts

geometry
basis
scf

The geometry and basis blocks are very similar to NWChem, in fact, the basis set format is the same for NWCehm
The scf block only accepts num_elec. This code ONLY does RHF. Single reference, closed-shell systems ONLY
I have tested this on a few compounds and it is about 10^-2 AU in energy different from results from PySCF. More work is needed.
I’m thinking of using this program as a starting point to add and test new libraries to run computational chemistry methods, esp to the Exascale.
Contact Me for any more information!
